Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Novel Non-Invasive Intracranial Pressure Monitoring Method
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to improve the treatment and decrease the high costs associated with treating patients who suffer severe traumatic brain injuries. This project aims to develop an accurate, affordable (<$100 per use) and non-invasive device to monitor a patient?s intracranial pressure following traumatic brain injury. Increased intracranial pressure can result in serious condition or death, if left untreated. However, the only available method to monitor intracranial pressure is expensive (~$10,000 per patient) and requires neurosurgery. The lack of a method to accurately screen patients to determine who needs surgery results in misdiagnoses and incorrect treatment in about 46% of patients among an estimated 50,000 patients in the US alone, and hundreds of thousands more globally. Successful commercialization of product is expected to result in savings in the range $250 million ever year to the US healthcare system.

The proposed project will test the feasibility of developing a non-invasive intracranial pressure (ICP) monitoring method for use outside of the neuro ICU. To develop an accurate, affordable, and non-invasive ICP monitoring device, the team will first write and validate a software framework that analyzes Cerebral Blood Flow Velocity (CBFV) waveforms. CBFV waveforms are acquired non-invasively by using transcranial Doppler (TCD) ultrasonography. In order to use CBFVs to predict ICP, two novel signal-processing methods will be developed. First, the high noise levels typical to TCD-acquired waveforms will be reduced within a machine-learning framework. Second, we will use a method to track morphological features that predict ICP from the CBFV waveform. Both these approaches to signal processing to analyze CBFV waveforms are entirely novel. This approach is expected to allow for accurate (>92% of area under the diagnostic ROC) non-invasive real time monitoring at an affordable price point that is within current reimbursement limits for TCD procedures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project demonstrated feasibility for developing a non-invasive intracranial pressure (ICP) monitoring method for use outside of the neuro intensive care unit. The results will directly lead to a novel software framework that can be uploaded to any commercial transcranial Doppler (TCD) device to accurately estimate ICP in real-time. Two novel signal-processing methods in a machine-learning framework were developed to analyze cerebral blood flow velocity (CBFV) waveforms obtained via TCD. The first method was developed to reduce the high noise levels typical to TCD-acquired CBFV waveforms using a learned manifold within a machine-learning framework. This method utilizes the pulsatile nature of the CBFV waveform to achieve this. The second method enabled the tracking of morphological features that characterize the CBFV waveform. This enables real-time extraction of these features and was developed to increase the accuracy of ICP estimation. Together, these enable increased accuracy in ICP estimation, and work in real-time since they analyze the CBFV waveform one pulse at a time. Both these approaches to signal processing to analyze CBFV waveforms are entirely novel. This approach allows for real time monitoring at an affordable price point that is within current reimbursement limits for TCD procedures. 

Clinical guidelines recommend ICP monitoring for patients with severe traumatic brain injury (TBI), subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), and conditions with risk of elevated ICP, since ICP can be fatal if left untreated. However, to date, the only reliable method for monitoring a patient’s ICP involves a neurosurgeon placing a pressure probe into the brain tissue or cerebral ventricles in the neuro ICU. Due to the expense and inherent risks of such a procedure, ICP monitoring is used sparingly. An estimated 40% of 275,000 U.S patients and millions more globally do not receive the recommended ICP monitoring. Neural Analytics, Inc. is addressing this significant need by developing an affordable (<$100 per use) and non-invasive ICP monitoring device. The first product will be a software package that can be loaded into any existing TCD ultrasound device to enable non-invasive ICP monitoring. The estimated market for the software product is about $50 MM. Subsequent products will be portable ICP monitors, allowing for ICP assessments in the field and areas that do not have access to adequate neuro critical care. The market size is considerably larger for the follow on products. Finally, the signal processing methods developed in this program will be applicable to almost any application that requires real-time and accurate predictions based on pulsatile signals. Examples of these include intelligent warning alarms for patient monitoring using pulsatile signals such as arterial blood pressure, oxygen saturation, etc. The methods are also likely to be applicable in several industrial process monitoring systems that use pulsatile signals.
